Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story:
I stare at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code review comments piling up in the chat. “Performance bottleneck here,” one says. “Can you refactor this loop?” another suggests. My mind races, searching for a cleaner, more efficient solution, but I can’t focus. From the hallway, I hear the washing machine’s insistent beep—laundry’s been sitting there since morning. My husband texted earlier, reminding me that our daughter needs her soccer uniform clean for tomorrow. I promised I’d handle it tonight. 

I glance at the clock. If I dive into the code now, I might lose track of time and forget the laundry again. But if I get up to sort and fold, I’ll break my flow, and the code review will have to wait. My team expects me to deliver polished work, but my family counts on me to keep things running at home. The weight of both expectations presses down, and I feel myself pulled in two directions, unable to satisfy either role without letting the other down.
